properties.title: User's Manual: Building an LDAP Test Plan

section.name: &sect-num;. Building an LDAP Test Plan
section.p:
In this section, you will learn how to create a basic Test Plan to test an LDAP server. You will create four users that send requests for four tests on the LDAP server. Also, you will tell the users to run their tests 4 times. So, the total number of requests is (4 users) x (4 requests) x (repeat 4 times) = 64 LDAP requests. To construct the Test Plan, you will use the following elements: Thread Group, , , and
.
This example assumes that the LDAP Server is available at ldap.test.com.

section.name: &sect-num;.1 Adding Users
section.p: The first step you want to do with every JMeter Test Plan is to add a Thread Group element. The Thread Group tells JMeter the number of users you want to simulate, how often the users should send requests, and the how many requests they should send.

Go ahead and add the ThreadGroup element by first selecting the Test Plan, clicking your right mouse button to get the Add menu, and then select
Add ThreadGroup . You should now see the Thread Group element under Test Plan. If you do not see the element, then "expand" the Test Plan tree by clicking on the Test Plan element.
Figure &sect-num;.1. Thread Group and final test tree

section.name: &sect-num;.2 Adding Login Config Element
section.p:
Begin by selecting the LDAP Users element. Click your right mouse button to get the Add menu, and then select
Add Config Element Login Config Element . Then, select this new element to view its Control Panel.
Like most JMeter elements, the Login Config Element's Control Panel has a name field that you can modify. In this example, leave this field with the default value.
section.figure: Figure &sect-num;.2 Login Config Element for our Test Plan

note.p:
Enter Username field to "your LDAP Username",
The password field to "your LDAP Password"
These values will be used by the LDAP Requests.

section.name: &sect-num;.3 Adding LDAP Request Defaults
section.p:
Begin by selecting the LDAP Users element. Click your right mouse button to get the Add menu, and then select
Add Config Element LDAP Request Defaults . Then, select this new element to view its Control Panel.
Like most JMeter elements, the LDAP Request Defaults Control Panel has a name field that you can modify. In this example, leave this field with the default value.
section.figure: Figure &sect-num;.3 LDAP Defaults for our Test Plan
section.note:
Enter DN field to "your LDAP Root Distinguished Name".
Enter LDAP Server's Servername field to "ldap.test.com".
The port to 389.
These values are default for the LDAP Requests.

section.name: &sect-num;.4 Adding LDAP Requests
section.p: In our Test Plan, we need to make four LDAP requests.

JMeter sends requests in the order that you add them to the tree. Start by adding the first LDAP Request to the LDAP Users element ( Add Sampler LDAP Request ). Then, select the LDAP Request element in the tree and edit the following properties

ol.li: Select the Add Test radio button in Test Configuration group

section.figure: Figure &sect-num;.4.1 LDAP Request for Inbuilt Add test
section.p: You do not have to set the Servername field, port field, Username, Password and DN because you already specified this value in the Login Config Element and LDAP Request Defaults.
Next, add the second LDAP Request and edit the following properties

ol.li: Select the Search Test radio button in Test Configuration group

section.p: Next, add the Third LDAP Request and edit the following properties
section.figure: Figure &sect-num;.4.2 LDAP Request for Inbuilt Search test

ol.li: Select the Modify Test radio button in Test Configuration group

section.p: Next, add the fourth LDAP Request and edit the following properties
section.figure: Figure &sect-num;.4.3 LDAP Request for Inbuilt Modify test

ol.li: Select the Delete Test radio button in Test Configuration group

section.figure: Figure &sect-num;.4.4 LDAP Request for Inbuilt Delete test

section.name: &sect-num;.5 Adding a Response Assertion
section.p: You can add a Response Assertion element. This element will check the received response data by verifying if the response text is "successful". ( Add Assertion Response Assertion ).
section.note: Note: A this position in the tree, the Response Assertion will be executed for each LDAP Request.

ol.li: Select Text Response Radio button in Response Field to Test group
Select Substring Radio button in Pattern Matching Rules group
Click on Add button and add the string "successful" in Pattern to Test field

section.name: &sect-num;.6 Adding a Listener to View/Store the Test Results
section.p: The final element you need to add to your Test Plan is a Listener. This element is responsible for storing all of the results of your LDAP requests in a file and presenting a visual model of the data. Select the LDAP Users element and add a View Results in Table ( Add Listener View Results in Table )
